Right click on the class, select Web Service->Create Web Service
Accept the defaults

Click next

The way I worked around this problem is:
1. reinstalling eclipse from scratch (version 3.1.1)
2. menu [help -->software updates -->find and install] to install WTP 0.7 *and*
all its dependancies

Probably installing WTP from zip file had previously left my system missing some
required dependancies...

I also can reproduce this behavior with a simple test case.  Using WTP 0.7.1, 
Eclipse 3.1.1, all correct dependencies installed (checked via the Find and 
Install Updates menu).

Start with a brand new workspace.  Setup the Tomcat 5.5 runtime under Window-
>Preferences to start with.  Create a new Java project.  Create a simple class 
called test.Hello, with a single method "public String sayHello(String msg)", 
implement the method as "return "Hello" + msg;" and then try to create a web 
service from it.  Click "Generate Proxy" and "Test Web Service" during 
deployment.  Use all default options otherwise.  Same failure.  I have Build 
Automatically set, so the class IS there under my output directory.

I have not, BTW, had any success with the reported "workarounds" above 
(rebuilding, recreating the workspace, etc).  All attempts with my current 
build, new workspaces, or other classes yield the same result I just mentioned.

Kathy, I'm targetting this to M9 though we haven't had debugged the problem 
yet. The scenario is very golden path, and should be working cleanly in our 
next milestone.

Note to all: Dave Rodenbaugh's comment makes mention of creating a Java 
project, and Java / Web project combos on the Tomcat (non J2EE) server won't 
work without explicitly adding the Java project's jar to the Tomcat server's 
classpath... Are others encountering this problem under that condition (ie. 
class in a Java project vs. in the Web project)?

I tested with the latest integration build candidate I200511091028 available at:

http://download.eclipse.org/webtools/committers/drops/I-I200511091028-
200511091028/

I can get through creating a bottom-up Web service with a bean in a dynamic Web 
project using Tomcat 5.5.9 and JDK 1.5_04.  I've also tested with Tomcat 5.0.28 
and JDK 1.4.2_09.

I had run through similar testing with WTP 0.7.1 and had no problem with the 
bottom-up Web service scenario with Tomcat 5.5 or Tomcat 5.0.

I suspect the root of the problem is the bean that the wizard is not able to 
find is in a Java project depended by the Web project when the wizard is run. 
This problem was in WTP 0.7.1.  I fixed that problem in defect 107808 
(https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=107808) in early October.  It 
would be available in recent drivers.

Please remember though even with the fix, you would have to add the JAR to the 
Web project's WebContent/WEB-INF/lib directory in order for the server to pick 
it up at runtime.

Please reopen the defect if you still encounter this problem with the latest 
driver and include detail steps to reproduce the problem.

*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 107808 ***

As we are trying to close down WTP 1.5, please get the latest WTP 1.5 driver to verify the bug and reopen if the problem had not been fixed.  If this defect is not verified/reopened by end of day 06/16, I'll attempt to verify the defect by reproducing the problem as described in the defect.  However, since you know your scenario best, it would be more appropriate if you verify the fix.

The problem is occurs with WTP 1.5.
I use Eclipse 3.2 with WTP 1.5.0-200606281455, Java 1.4.2_05 and Tomcat 5.0.28.

I get the same ClassNotFoundException when I refer to a class in an external project. I have to package the classes into a jar-File and integrate this in the WebService project.

Please note that if you're trying to create a Web service on bean in a Web project (WebProj) that depends on a Java project (JavaProj), you would have to either:

1. Bring up project properties on WebProj and specify JavaProj as it's J2EE module dependency.

2. Bring up project properties on WebProj, add JavaProj as a dependent project under Java Build Path.  Then, JAR up the classes in the JavaProj and copy it into the WebContent/WEB-INF/lib directory of the WebProj.  Without doing this last step would result in error in deploying Web service to Axis.

I've just retried the scenario with WTP 1.5.1 09220504 driver and I could create a Web service no problem with dependent project using either one of the approaches above.

Closing the defect.  Please re-open this defect or open another one if this is still a problem

I found a strange workaround - if I try to create a Web Service only, I get the ClassNotFoundException; if I try to create a Web Service *and* a Web Service Client in the same dialog, it goes through just fine and creates both.
